results_summary: The study found that lyophilized milk kefir loaded with SNESNS significantly improved body weight, intestinal mucosa, neurotransmitter levels, memory functions, and gut microbiota, while reducing inflammation and oxidative stress. It outperformed kefir alone in alleviating gut-brain axis disorders.
population_specificity: Rats with induced chronic IBD-like symptoms.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg lyophilized milk kefir with 10 mg/kg Caraway oil and 1 mg/kg licorice extract, administered daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate kefir as an alternative to antibiotics for reducing necrotic enteritis (NE) and improving live performance in broilers.
results_summary: Kefir (20% in drinking water) reduced C. perfringens infection and mortality, with no detrimental effects on broiler live performance. The combination of kefir and black cumin seeds was most effective, significantly lowering mortality and Cp populations.
population_specificity: Cobb 500 male broilers (poultry).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the molecular mechanisms and metabolites in goat milk kefir that contribute to its health benefits, comparing raw and pasteurized milk fermentation.
results_summary: The study detected 105 metabolites in kefir, with 27 differing between raw and pasteurized milk, suggesting pasteurization affects microbial populations. Key molecules like shikimic acid, GABA, and tyramine were linked to antibacterial properties, immune support, and arterial pressure. NIRS monitoring achieved 90% accuracy in classifying fermentation stages.
population_specificity: Goat milk kefir samples (specific human population not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir extract (KE) could reverse intestinal damage caused by oxytetracycline (OTC) exposure in zebrafish larvae.
results_summary: KE treatment significantly improved intestinal health by reducing proinflammatory factors, increasing antioxidant levels, and restoring microbiota balance, though it only partially reversed morphological damage. KE also enhanced intestinal motility.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae exposed to OTC from 3 to 8 days post-fertilization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of kefir against cyclophosphamide-induced heart and liver toxicity in rats.
results_summary: Kefir reduced oxidative stress markers and improved heart and liver tissue damage in rats treated with cyclophosphamide, bringing biochemical parameters closer to control levels. The study demonstrated kefir's cytoprotective effect against drug-induced toxicity.
population_specificity: Wistar albino rats
interactions: Cyclophosphamide (positive interaction where kefir mitigated its toxicity)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kefir peptides (KPs) could prevent bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis in mice by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and fibrosis, and modulating gut microbiota.
results_summary: KPs pretreatment prevented bodyweight loss, improved pulmonary function, restored lung tissue structure, reduced oxidative and inflammatory markers, and altered gut microbiota composition in bleomycin-treated mice.
population_specificity: Bleomycin-induced pulmonary fibrosis model in mice.
study_duration: 4 days pretreatment followed by 21 days post-bleomycin exposure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the ability of water kefir grains (WKGs) to remove aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) and determine the mechanism of absorption and detoxification effects in various settings.
results_summary: WKGs effectively removed AFB1 across a range of concentrations, pH levels, and temperatures, primarily through absorption. They also reduced AFB1-induced mutagenicity and decreased AFB1 levels in cow milk and tea soups by over 54%.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and food/feed applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of the kefir yeast Kluyveromyces marxianus A4 (Km A4) in combination with sulfasalazine in mice with DSS-induced colitis.
results_summary: The combination of Km A4 and sulfasalazine (A4 + S) showed the lowest histological score, downregulated pro-inflammatory markers (Il-6, Tnf-α, Cox-2), upregulated anti-inflammatory markers (Il-10, Ocln), and enhanced Bacteroides abundance in gut microbiota compared to the DSS group.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice with dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of kefir supernatant (KS) on the initiation and progression of ulcerative colitis (UC) in a murine model.
results_summary: KS supplementation improved UC symptoms, reduced pro-inflammatory cytokines, increased anti-inflammatory cytokines, protected the colon barrier, and restored gut microbiota balance by increasing beneficial bacteria (Blautia, Akkermansia) and decreasing harmful bacteria (Bacteroides). It also altered colon metabolism, particularly in the l-arginine biosynthesis pathway.
population_specificity: UC murine model (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of kefir supplementation on ADHD symptomatology, sleep, attention, and gut microbiome composition in children diagnosed with ADHD.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study appears to be in progress or not yet concluded.
population_specificity: Children aged 8-13 years diagnosed with ADHD in the UK.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the viability and bioactive properties of kefir-like products made from dairy by-products (AWP, BM, SWP, SWP+MFGM) with traditional kefir milks.
results_summary: SWP and SWP+MFGM were the most viable by-products for kefir fermentation, showing diverse microbial abundance and positive bioactive properties. All products achieved a 6-log reduction against Listeria innocua and Escherichia coli, with traditional kefirs having the highest antioxidant capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and cell-based assays, no human participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of milk kefir against NSAID-induced gastric ulcers and explore its antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.
results_summary: Pretreatment with kefir for 14 days prevented gastric lesions, reduced ROS production, DNA fragmentation, apoptosis, and TNF-α levels, while increasing NO bioavailability and IL-10 levels. Kefir peptides showed affinity with NADPH oxidase 2, suggesting its gastroprotective mechanism.
population_specificity: Male Swiss mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of kefir supplementation on alcohol-induced liver injury in mice.
results_summary: Kefir treatment improved liver pathology, reduced inflammatory markers and liver enzymes (ALT, AST), increased antioxidant levels, restored the intestinal barrier, and modulated gut microbiota composition and bile acid metabolism.
population_specificity: C57BL/6J mice with alcohol-induced liver injury.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize and compare the anti-inflammatory properties of novel kefir exopolysaccharides (KEPS) and traditional kefiran (KE) in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: Both KEPS and KE significantly reduced IL-6 secretion in LPS-stimulated macrophages and inhibited NF-κB signaling in mice, effectively suppressing inflammatory mediators like p-MAPK and IL-6 in multiple organs. KEPS showed potential to alleviate LPS-induced systemic damage by inhibiting NF-κB/MAPK signaling.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages and male/female NF-κB-luciferase+/+ transgenic mice.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg orally for both KEPS and KE.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-diabetic potential of Lactobacillus paracasei isolated from Malaysian water kefir grains in a type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) model.
results_summary: The isolated L. paracasei improved glucose homeostasis and lipid metabolism in diabetic mice, reducing insulin resistance and regulating gene expression related to these processes. Both low-dose and high-dose treatments showed significant improvements compared to untreated diabetic mice.
population_specificity: High-fat diet/streptozotocin-induced diabetic mice.
effective_dosage: Low-dose and high-dose concentrations (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir, alone or in combination with yacon, could improve bone and intestinal health in rats.
results_summary: Kefir improved immunity by increasing secretory immunoglobulin A secretion and reduced bone resorption biomarkers, but the combination with yacon did not show a synbiotic effect.
population_specificity: Forty Wistar male rats divided into four groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of commercial or traditional kefir supplementation on macronutrient digestibility, fecal characteristics, microbiota populations, and metabolite and IgA concentrations in healthy adult dogs.
results_summary: Kefir supplementation had minor effects on fecal microbiota populations and metabolite concentrations but did not significantly impact macronutrient digestibility, fecal characteristics, or IgA levels. Traditional kefir showed a greater relative abundance of Lactococcus, while commercial kefir had a higher relative abundance of Fusobacteriota.
population_specificity: Healthy adult dogs (12 dogs, average age 5.67 years, average weight 7.27 kg).
effective_dosage: 60 mL/day of either commercial kefir, traditional kefir, or lactase-treated milk (control).
study_duration: Three 28-day periods (22-day transition, 5-day fecal collection, 1-day blood collection per period).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether milk kefir consumption could reduce depression symptoms in individuals with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that while the Diet + Kefir group showed a significant reduction in depression scores, between-group analyses did not show significant differences, suggesting kefir may not effectively reduce depression symptoms in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Adults with grades 1 to 3 of NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of vacuum evaporation and freeze-drying on volatile organic compound concentration, sensory quality, and microbial viability in commercial kefir.
results_summary: Both vacuum evaporation and freeze-drying significantly reduced volatile organic compound concentrations by an average of 61%, with differences in the reduction of specific compound classes. While these treatments did not significantly improve average consumer acceptance, they altered the range of acceptability responses and slightly reduced concentrations of Lactobacillus and Lactococcus species.
population_specificity: Not specified (commercial kefir product tested, not a human or animal population).
effective_dosage: Not specified (plain, unsweetened commercial kefir with 1% milkfat was used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the microbiota profile of milk kefir and its effects on metabolism, oxidative stress, and the microbiota-gut-brain axis in a murine model.
results_summary: Kefir increased antioxidant enzymes (catalase and superoxide dismutase) in the colon, elevated SCFAs (butyrate and propionate) in feces and brain, reduced triglycerides and uric acid, and promoted the growth of butyrate-producing bacteria (Lachnospiraceae and Lachnoclostridium). These changes suggest kefir positively influences the gut-microbiota-brain axis and supports gut and brain health.
population_specificity: C57BL-6 mice (n=20)
effective_dosage: 0.1 mL (10% w/v) kefir administered via gavage

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate new biopolymeric blend materials using water kefir grains and yeast biomasses for improved properties in food packaging applications.
results_summary: Blending water kefir and yeast biomasses enhanced thermal stability, mechanical properties, and homogeneity of the films, with increased water kefir content improving transparency, thermal stability, and elongation at break. The materials showed strong interpolymeric interactions and suitability for food packaging.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on biomaterials)
effective_dosage: Varying ratios of water kefir to yeast (100/0, 75/25, 50/50, 25/75, 0/100)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of kefir beverage on cardiometabolic risk factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Kefir intake significantly reduced fasting insulin and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) but showed no significant effects on total cholesterol, triglycerides, HDL-C, LDL-C, fasting blood sugar, HbA1c, or body weight.
population_specificity: 314 subjects from six randomized controlled trials (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir peptides (KPs) could prevent vascular calcification (VC) and osteoporosis in ApoE -/- mice fed a high-cholesterol atherogenic diet.
results_summary: KPs reduced serum cholesterol, oxidative stress, and inflammatory markers, inhibited atherosclerotic plaque calcification, and improved bone density and structure in ApoE -/- mice.
population_specificity: ApoE -/- mice and wild-type C57BL/6 mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the metabolic health effects of commercial kefir versus pitched kefir containing traditional organisms on plasma lipid levels, glucose homeostasis, and markers of endothelial function and inflammation in males with elevated LDL cholesterol.
results_summary: Pitched kefir reduced LDL-C, ICAM-1, and VCAM-1 compared to baseline, while commercial kefir increased TNF-α. Pitched kefir also showed greater reductions in IL-8, CRP, VCAM-1, and TNF-α compared to commercial kefir, indicating microbial composition influences health benefits.
population_specificity: Males with elevated LDL cholesterol (n=21).
study_duration: Two 4-week treatment periods separated by a 4-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the probiotic properties of Kefir yeast strains (Km A4 and Km A5), including their gut microbiota modulation and adherence to intestinal cells, compared to Saccharomyces boulardii.
results_summary: The kefir yeast strains showed higher intestinal cell adhesion than Sb MYA-796 and modulated gut microbiota in mice, increasing Bacteroidetes and Corynebacteriales abundances at specific dosages.
population_specificity: BALB/c mice (healthy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the microbiota and peptidomic composition of raw milk kefir and evaluate its potential anti-allergic effects using a murine food allergy model.
results_summary: Raw milk kefir showed additional microbial diversity compared to heated milk kefir and suppressed acute allergic skin responses in sensitized mice, coinciding with differences in T-cell activity. Heating milk reduced peptide diversity in kefir and diminished its anti-allergic effects.
population_specificity: Sensitized mice in a food allergy model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review clinical studies on kefir as a therapeutic agent to compile results and guide future research.
results_summary: The review found that kefir is safe for people without serious illnesses, but small sample sizes, methodological variations, and differences in kefir types, dosage, and treatment duration prevented clear conclusions about its benefits for specific diseases.
population_specificity: Humans across various health areas, including metabolic syndrome, gastrointestinal health, maternal/child health, dentistry, oncology, women's/geriatric health, and dermatology.
effective_dosage: Not standardized; suggested using a dose in milliliters according to body weight.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the chemical, texture, rheology, microstructure, and water distribution of kefir yoghurt fermented by mixed bacteria versus L. plantarum L1, and to evaluate its nutritional and flavor differences from ordinary yoghurt.
results_summary: The study found that kefir yoghurt had higher water content but lower water-holding capacity, weaker protein network connections, and increased protein network density. It also had enhanced volatile flavor compounds, such as phenylethyl alcohol and isoamyl alcohol, contributing to a unique taste profile resembling traditional kefir champagne yoghurt.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food model study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of kefir peptides (KPs) in alleviating adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) in a rat model and explore their anti-inflammatory mechanisms in human synovial cells.
results_summary: KPs reduced synovitis and bone erosion in AIA rats by inhibiting IL-1β-related inflammation and MMPs production, with comparable effects to tofacitinib. In vitro, KPs attenuated inflammatory cytokine production and MMPs expression in IL-1β-treated human synovial cells.
population_specificity: Adjuvant-induced arthritis (AIA) rat model and IL-1β-treated human synovial cell line (SW982).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of kefir intake on gastrointestinal (GI) symptoms in healthy individuals and those with atopic dermatitis (AD), as well as its potential role in modulating the gut-skin axis.
results_summary: Kefir intake significantly improved GI status, including functional constipation, abdominal pain intensity, and abdominal distension. The study also established a relationship between improved skin parameters and GI status, reinforcing kefir's potential as a modulator of the gut-skin axis in both healthy and atopic individuals.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and those with atopic dermatitis (AD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify a probiotic strain, specifically Lactobacillus kefiranofaciens ZW18, that enhances the anti-tumor effects of PD-1 inhibitors in melanoma treatment.
results_summary: ZW18 demonstrated the best anti-melanoma effect among tested probiotics, inhibiting tumor growth by 66.16% in PD-1-treated mice, enhancing immunity, increasing CD8+ T cell infiltration, and optimizing gut microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Murine (mice) with melanoma treated with PD-1 inhibitors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the osteoprotective effects of kefir peptides (KPs) in AKR1A1eGFP/eGFP mice and uncover their mechanism in modulating bone remodeling.
results_summary: KPs reduced proinflammatory cytokines and bone resorption markers while increasing bone formation markers, prevented bone loss, enhanced bone elasticity and hardness, and promoted osteoblast differentiation while inhibiting osteoclast differentiation.
population_specificity: Male AKR1A1eGFP/eGFP mice (vitamin C-deficient model) and male CD-1 mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of kefir peptides (KPs) in promoting fracture healing in a rat model and assess their osteogenic effects in vitro.
results_summary: KPs treatment improved fracture healing progression, increased osteogenic gene expression in fractured rats, and enhanced osteogenic differentiation and mineralization in cell cultures.
population_specificity: 8-week-old male Sprague Dawley rats and mouse bone marrow mesenchymal stem cells (BMMSCs) and MC3T3-E1 cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Kefir's potential to regulate intestinal microbiota, enhance immune response, and stimulate the development and maturation of intestinal mucosal immunity.
results_summary: Kefir was found to regulate intestinal microbiota balance, enhance immune response through metabolites like SCFAs and EPS, and maintain intestinal homeostasis by modulating SIgA and IL-10 levels. Early intervention with Kefir may help seize critical periods for mucosal immunity development.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the evidence from randomized controlled trials on the effects of fermented-milk kefir on human health outcomes.
results_summary: Kefir may help reduce oral Streptococcus mutans (lowering dental caries risk) and aid in Helicobacter pylori eradication, as well as potentially improve adult dyslipidemia and hypertension, though evidence was limited. Safety was only assessed in a few studies, and most had a high risk of bias.
population_specificity: Generally healthy populations and individuals with specific conditions (e.g., dyslipidemia, hypertension, oral/gastric microbiota issues).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary Kefir supplementation could mitigate the harmful effects of aflatoxin B1 (AFB1) on Nile tilapia by improving biometric, biochemical, and histological parameters.
results_summary: Kefir supplementation significantly improved weight gain, antioxidant enzyme activities (CAT, GPx, SOD), and liver health in Nile tilapia exposed to AFB1, while reducing liver malonaldehyde content and preventing degenerative liver changes.
population_specificity: Nile tilapia (Oreochromis niloticus)
effective_dosage: Not specified (Kefir was included in the diet)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tibetan kefir (TK) could prevent ochratoxin A (OTA)-induced intestinal barrier disruption in mice.
results_summary: TK reversed OTA-driven histopathological changes, increased cecal mucin levels, elevated tight junction protein expression, suppressed oxidative stress, reduced inflammation via the NF-κB pathway, and modulated gut microbiota by depleting harmful bacteria while supporting SCFA-producing bacteria.
population_specificity: Mice exposed to OTA
effective_dosage: Oral gavage once daily (specific amount not stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore kefir's potential as a source of bioactive peptides capable of modulating the amyloidogenic pathway and reducing oxidative stress in Alzheimer's disease (AD).
results_summary: Kefir peptide-rich fractions showed therapeutic potential for AD by improving motor performance, brain morphology, and reducing oxidative stress in AD-like flies, with molecular docking supporting their interaction with pathology-related proteins.
population_specificity: Drosophila melanogaster (AD-like flies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Kefir could protect against the decline in sperm quality caused by a high-fat diet in adult rats.
results_summary: Kefir improved sperm density, viability, mobility, and reduced morphological abnormalities in rats on a high-fat diet. It also corrected lipid profiles and maintained normal spermatogenesis compared to the high-fat diet group.
population_specificity: Adult male rats
effective_dosage: 1 ml/100 g body weight of Kefir milk

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Lactobacillus kefiranofaciens JKSP109 (LK) and Saccharomyces cerevisiae JKSP39 (SC) from Tibetan kefir grain could alleviate colon inflammation and colorectal carcinogenesis in a mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that LK, SC, and their combination improved body weight, reduced disease activity and tumor multiplicity, positively regulated gut microbiota, enhanced gut barrier function, decreased proinflammatory cytokines, and increased apoptosis in tumor cells. The combination treatment showed superior effects compared to single strains.
population_specificity: AOM/DSS-induced colorectal cancer mouse model.
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered for five days per week).
study_duration: From the day of AOM administration (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and melanogenesis inhibition capacities of Tibetan kefir grain milk whey (TKG-MW) after 3 and 6 days of fermentation.
results_summary: TKG-MW at 6 days of fermentation showed higher antioxidant activity and anti-inflammatory effects compared to 3 days. It also inhibited melanin synthesis by downregulating key genes and proteins involved in melanogenesis, and organic acids in TKG-MW significantly suppressed tyrosinase activity.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using RAW 264.7 macrophages and B16-F10 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of goat milk kefir (with and without porang glucomannan) on blood glucose, HbA1c, FFAs, TNF-α, PPARg gene expression, and insulin-producing cells in rats fed a high-fat, high-fructose diet.
results_summary: Synbiotic kefir reduced HbA1c, TNF-α, and PPARγ2 gene expression while inhibiting FFAs, but did not significantly affect plasma glucose levels or insulin-producing cells. Probiotic kefir's effects were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats fed a high-fat, high-fructose diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of kefir peptides (KPs) on osteoporosis in coagulation factor VIII gene knockout mice (F8KO), a model of hemophilia A.
results_summary: KPs increased trabecular bone mineral density, bone volume, and trabecular number while decreasing trabecular separation in F8KO mice. The treatment also reduced serum RANKL/OPG ratio and IL-6 levels, indicating inhibition of osteoclastogenesis.
population_specificity: Male F8KO mice at 20 weeks of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of milk Kefir (MK) combined with resistance exercise on bone loss in rats with glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIO).
results_summary: The study found that MK combined with resistance exercise (ExK) significantly improved bone microarchitecture, quality, and metabolism, including increased trabecular bone volume density, cortical volume, and collagen maturity, while reversing osteoblast reduction and enhancing biomechanical properties. MK alone and exercise alone also showed benefits, but the combination (ExK) produced the most significant improvements.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with glucocorticoid-induced osteoporosis (GIO).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vivo anti-hypertensive, antioxidant, and anti-inflammatory effects of the Kef-1 peptide derived from kefir in an angiotensin II-dependent hypertension model.
results_summary: The Kef-1 peptide demonstrated potential anti-hypertensive effects, systemic antioxidant and anti-inflammatory activities, reduced ROS production in smooth muscle cells, and improved aortic wall-thickening and endothelial structure in hypertensive mice.
population_specificity: 2K1C mice (angiotensin II-dependent hypertension model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether kefir supplementation could mitigate testicular degeneration and related molecular changes induced by a high-fructose diet in rats.
results_summary: Kefir supplementation counteracted fructose-induced testicular degeneration by upregulating protective proteins (claudin-11, SIRT1, JNK1, p-JNK1) and suppressing mitogenic and apoptotic factors in fructose-fed rats.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (4 weeks old)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of homemade kefir intake on skin health in healthy and atopic volunteers, particularly focusing on skin barrier function and atopic dermatitis (AD) severity.
results_summary: Kefir intake improved skin barrier function in both healthy and atopic individuals and reduced the severity of AD in atopic volunteers, with notable benefits for skin hydration. The effects likely stem from kefir's complex microbiota, metabolites, and nutrients.
population_specificity: Healthy and atopic (AD) volunteers

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare bioactive compounds in industrial and artisanal kefir, assess their health effects, and determine differences in functional potential between the two types.
results_summary: Kefir's bioactive compounds (exopolysaccharides, peptides, organic acids) showed antimicrobial, anticancer, and immune-modulatory effects, with significant differences between industrial and artisanal kefir. Clinical evidence is needed to confirm practical applicability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies summarized).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether milk kefir could prevent the negative effects of high fructose corn syrup (HFCS) on craniomandibular bone development in early age.
results_summary: The study found that HFCS consumption reduced osteoblastic activity and increased osteoclastic activity in craniomandibular bones, but kefir intake significantly suppressed these negative effects. Kefir demonstrated potential as a preventive treatment for HFCS-induced bone development issues.
population_specificity: Early-age subjects (specific age not mentioned).
effective_dosage: Not specified (kefir administered via gastric gavage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of 12 weeks of postexercise kefir consumption on body composition, psychological state, and inflammatory biomarkers in cancer survivors who had undergone chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.
results_summary: Kefir consumption improved lean body mass (6.3%), reduced depression (51.4%), fatigue (39.3%), and gastric distress (64.7%), and lowered circulating LPS (35.4%). It also increased classical monocytes (18.0%) and decreased nonclassical monocytes (22.3%).
population_specificity: Cancer survivors (N = 24; 9 males, 15 females; average age 61 ± 9.9 years) who had undergone chemotherapy and/or radiation therapy.
effective_dosage: 8 oz. of kefir after exercise sessions (3 times per week).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether probiotics fermentation technology (PFT), a kefir product, could enhance insulin signaling via gut microbiota modulation to halt Alzheimer's disease (AD) progression, comparing its effectiveness to pioglitazone.
results_summary: PFT reversed neurodegeneration and cognitive impairment, increased hippocampal acetylcholine levels, reduced β-amyloid levels, improved insulin signaling, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammation, with effects comparable to pioglitazone.
population_specificity: Mice with induced Alzheimer's disease via intracerebroventricular streptozotocin injection.
effective_dosage: 100, 200, and 400 mg/kg of PFT; 30 mg/kg of pioglitazone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effect of kefir milk and other probiotic products on reducing salivary Streptococcus mutans levels in children with initial carious lesions.
results_summary: Kefir milk and probiotic curd showed an equal and marked reduction in Streptococcus mutans colony-forming units (CFUs) compared to a probiotic drink, with effects observed within 1 hour and sustained over 30 days.
population_specificity: 8-12-year-old school children with initial carious lesions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir could ameliorate behavioral deficits and modulate immune responses in a mouse model relevant to autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Kefir decreased repetitive behavior, prolonged stress-induced corticosterone increases, ameliorated innate immune responses, increased anti-inflammatory Treg cells, and modulated gut microbiome composition and function in ASD-relevant mice.
population_specificity: BTBR T+ Itpr3tf/J mouse strain (a model relevant to ASD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of kefir beverage on glycemic control, specifically focusing on fasting blood sugar (FBS), hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c), and insulin levels.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that kefir significantly reduced FBS and insulin levels but did not significantly affect HbA1c. Overall, kefir showed beneficial effects on glycemic control, though more research is needed to clarify its mechanisms.
population_specificity: 323 subjects across six randomized controlled trials (RCTs).
study_duration: Varied across studies (not specified in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate kefir's efficacy in regulating gut microbiota and ameliorating colorectal cancer in a mouse model induced by AOM/DSS.
results_summary: Kefir reduced tumor size and quantity, decreased inflammatory and proliferation markers, increased beneficial short-chain fatty acids, and improved gut microbiota composition by boosting probiotics and reducing pathogens.
population_specificity: AOM/DSS-induced colorectal cancer mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of multi-strain AB-Kefir on diet-induced obesity and intestinal dysbiosis in mice fed high-fat and western diets.
results_summary: AB-Kefir reduced body weight gain, glucose intolerance, and hepatic steatosis in high-fat diet-fed mice but not in western diet-fed mice. It also regulated adipose tissue gene expression and showed correlations between specific gut microbiota and metabolic parameters.
population_specificity: Mice fed control, high-fat (60% kcal fat), or western (40% kcal fat) diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of kefir supplementation as an adjuvant therapy for Rasmussen encephalitis (RE), focusing on seizure control, cognitive improvement, and inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Kefir supplementation reduced seizure frequency and severity, improved cognitive and language function, decreased pro-inflammatory cytokines, increased anti-inflammatory cytokines, and enhanced gut microbiota by increasing Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium species.
population_specificity: A young male patient with Rasmussen encephalitis under pharmacotherapy for epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-oxidative, anti-apoptotic, and neuroprotective effects of kefir on human SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells.
results_summary: Kefir B demonstrated the highest antioxidant and cytoprotective effects, with significant reductions in oxidative stress and cell necrosis, as well as preservation of cellular integrity. The effects were linked to upregulation of SOD and catalase and modulation of apoptotic genes.
population_specificity: Human SH-SY5Y neuroblastoma cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the effects of Tibet kefir milk (TKM) on gut microbiota and metabolism in an obesity model using human-microbiota-associated rats.
results_summary: TKM intervention altered gut microbiota and metabolomics, restoring bile acid metabolism, modifying amino acid metabolism, and elevating anti-obesity factors, which contributed to reduced fat deposition. The study noted specific metabolite changes in TKM groups compared to the high-fat diet group.
population_specificity: Human-microbiota-associated rats fed a high-fat diet to establish an obesity model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential benefits of kefir, particularly its postbiotic kefiran, in treating food allergies and its role in developing nutraceutical products.
results_summary: The abstract highlights kefir's nutritional and therapeutic properties, with kefiran showing potential beneficial effects on food allergies by modulating the intestinal microbiome and immune system. It suggests kefiran could be an alternative therapy for food allergies.
population_specificity: People of all age groups, with a focus on babies and children affected by food allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of kefir supplementation on metabolic disorders induced by a high-fructose diet in rats, focusing on the intestine-liver-adipose tissue axis.
results_summary: Kefir supplementation improved metabolic parameters, reduced hepatic lipogenesis and inflammation, enhanced insulin signaling, and altered fecal microbiota in fructose-fed rats. It also attenuated intestinal permeability factors and improved tight-junction protein expression.
population_specificity: Rats fed a high-fructose diet for 15 weeks.
effective_dosage: Administered by gastric gavage once daily for the final six weeks (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of Lactobacillus kefiri CIDCA 8348 on intestinal T cells from patients with active inflammatory bowel disease (IBD).
results_summary: L. kefiri reduced spontaneous release of IL-6 and IL-8 from inflamed biopsies and decreased secretion of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6, IFN-γ, IL-13) in activated T cells from IBD patients. It also increased the frequency of regulatory CD4+FOXP3+ T cells and IL-10 levels.
population_specificity: Adult patients with active IBD (n = 19) and healthy donors (n = 5).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate kefir's potential to mitigate benzene-induced toxicity, particularly its effects on hematological and bone marrow parameters in rats.
results_summary: Kefir treatment alleviated benzene-associated weight loss, increased blood and bone marrow cell counts, and reduced pro-inflammatory cytokine expression, suggesting protective effects against benzene toxicity. Fecal analysis indicated high concentrations of lactic acid bacteria, correlating with kefir's beneficial outcomes.
population_specificity: Female rats exposed to benzene.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory and antiresorptive effects of milk kefir (MK) on periodontitis in rats, specifically assessing how fermentation time influences these effects.
results_summary: Four-day fermented MK showed higher intensity of Lactobacillus kefiri and reduced inflammation spectrum compared to one-day fermented MK. K4+EP group exhibited significant reduction in alveolar bone loss, lower pro-inflammatory cytokine expression (IL-6, TNF-α, IL-Iβ), and higher anti-inflammatory IL-10 expression compared to EP groups.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (administered 28 days before EP induction and during 11-day disease development).
study_duration: 39 days total (28 days pre-induction + 11 days post-induction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir could mitigate the antioxidative and inflammatory effects of high-fructose corn syrup (HFCS) in the gingival tissue and masseter muscle of rats.
results_summary: Kefir improved HFCS-induced inflammation and oxidative stress by reducing proinflammatory markers (IL-6, IL-1β, TNF-α) and restoring antioxidant enzyme activity (catalase, superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase) in both tissues.
population_specificity: Rats (animal study)
effective_dosage: Kefir supplementation via gastric gavage (exact dosage not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore how kefir may modulate gut microbiota and its potential benefits in preventing and managing chronic non-communicable diseases such as obesity, diabetes, liver disease, cardiovascular disorders, and neurological disorders.
results_summary: The study suggests that kefir contains peptides and bioactive compounds that can modulate gut microbiota, reduce low-grade inflammation, and improve intestinal permeability, potentially offering health benefits. However, further research is needed to standardize bioactive compounds and clarify mechanisms.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on Latin America due to socioeconomic factors.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether kefir (SYNKEFIR™) could improve exercise performance, reduce fatigue, and enhance physiological adaptability in humans.
results_summary: Supplementation with SYNKEFIR™ significantly increased exercise time to exhaustion, reduced lactate levels during and after exercise, and accelerated recovery, with no adverse reactions reported. No significant changes in gut microbiota or body composition were observed.
population_specificity: Sixteen healthy subjects aged 20-30 years.
study_duration: 28 days of supplementation, followed by a 28-day wash-out period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate kefir's potential as a therapeutic agent for Alzheimer's disease by examining its effects on microbiome modulation and amyloidogenic pathways in a Drosophila melanogaster model.
results_summary: Kefir and its fractions improved climbing ability, survival rate, and neurodegeneration index in AD-like flies, suggesting potential benefits in modulating amyloidogenic pathways.
population_specificity: Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) with an Alzheimer's disease-like condition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of kefir-induced juglone and resveratrol fractions (JRK) on apoptotic and anti-apoptotic pathways in Ehrlich Ascites Carcinoma (EAC)-bearing mice.
results_summary: JRK normalized EAC-induced dysregulation of Bcl-2 and Caspase-3 in mice plasma and upregulated apoptotic proteins (Bax, p53, Caspase-3,8,9, APAF-1) while downregulating anti-apoptotic proteins (Bcl-2, Bcl-xl) in EAC cells, suggesting potential benefits in cancer treatment.
population_specificity: BALB/c male mice with Ehrlich Ascites Carcinoma (EAC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytotoxic effects of kefir on glioblastoma cancer cells (U87 cell line) to determine its potential as a replacement or complementary cancer therapy.
results_summary: The study found that kefir, particularly its 48-hour fermented supernatant, exhibited dose-dependent cytotoxicity against glioblastoma cells, significantly reducing cell survival compared to the control group. The toxicity effect was most pronounced at higher concentrations.
population_specificity: U87 glioblastoma cancer cell line (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Different concentrations of kefir drink and supernatants (specific amounts not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the anti-inflammatory effect of Lactobacillus kefirgranum PRCC-1301-derived extracellular vesicles (PRCC-1301 EVs) on intestinal inflammation and barrier function.
results_summary: PRCC-1301 EVs inhibited pro-inflammatory cytokine expression, enhanced intestinal barrier function, and attenuated colitis symptoms in both acute and chronic murine models. The treatment also reduced phosphorylated NF-κB p65 and IκBα in colon tissues.
population_specificity: Human intestinal epithelial cells (Caco-2) and murine colitis models (acute DSS-induced and chronic IL-10-/- mice).
